{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3736619,"name":"Matthew Vorpahl","username":"MatthewV","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/82dd89/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-11T15:59:10.456Z","cooked":"

So my team used reversible bumpers for the first time this year. With the new rules we made it one solid frame that was robustly attached via an Angle bracket bolted to the bumper back by 2 t-nuts. Attached to the chassis by 2 10-32 SHCS going into rivnuts. We have an off-season comp coming up in November where we regularly need to fit through a standard 30 inch door way. which will only happen with no bumpers. Below is a picture sketch of what the attachment looks like. If anyone has any idea of how we can easily make these quick release that would be great.

Screenshot 2025-09-11 10.57.11 AM475×328 13.9 KB

Consider removing the screws, loctiting long setscrews (or threaded rod) into the rivnuts, and using regular nuts on the top of the angle. Essentially, convert to studs.

Alternatively, you could use rivnut studs, or another type of stud.

It doesn’t change much about the way the bumpers attach, but it forces the alignment to happen when all of the fasteners are loose. It also allows you to use “nuts” that are much softer (e.g., aluminum hex standoffs).

Also, you may be able to get away with using fewer nuts, because the studs will act as pins. Helpful if you’re running late in elims – half the fasteners is better than missing the match.

I do recommend power tools as well, but I suggest a drill with the clutch set low instead of an impact.

An electric screwdriver would probably work better for this. I’ve used mine a couple of times to remove swerve pods and bumpers and it worked great!

worx.com

4V 3-Speed Screwdriver

The 4V cordless screwdriver by Worx features 3 torque settings to tackle all common driving functions. Dual LED lights & easy USB charging. Shop today.

Price: USD 49.99

Yeah I had the idea to do the air hose thing last year, it worked really well. Here are the links to where it is duscussed:

Team 5000 2025 bot overview General Forum
This is an atypical robot CAD release in that I am going to go into detail in certain parts of my design and talk about some in my opinion innovative things that we came up with this season. This will be a living topic, so as I have time, I will continue to add to it. Some of the first things will be our bumper mounts, our quick detach protective plate, and our undermounted electronics. Robot CAD - Cursed Robot CAD - Less Cursed Off Season Robot CAD You might be asking, why 3 different CADs.…
Am I crazy? General Forum
[PXL_20250405_163027630] [PXL_20250405_162907687] [PXL_20250405_162445939] [PXL_20250405_162439649] [PXL_20250405_162405665] [PXL_20250405_134220377] I’ll definitely be stealing some of these features for future designs. They used quick disconnects for bumper mounting, and quarter turn auto body panel mounts for their brain pan protector. To store the bumper connectors they had tpu prints on the cart. Really clever stuff. Seriously incredible kids - I am looking forward to working with …

usbcd36:

Consider removing the screws, loctiting long setscrews (or threaded rod) into the rivnuts, and using regular nuts on the top of the angle. Essentially, convert to studs.

This is huge and will likely be much more durable than threading into the rivnuts. I mean it works but I still have nightmares from the year we did that at 4241 because when we got to the competition, it took us 90+ minutes to remove the bumpers as folks had managed to drive the mounting screws into the rivnuts at wicked angles basically cross threading or stripping the threads and the ones that didn’t have their threads mauled were torqued so tight they spun the rivnut. It was a nightmare.

Going to studs is a great idea.

usbcd36:

Consider removing the screws, loctiting long setscrews (or threaded rod) into the rivnuts, and using regular nuts on the top of the angle. Essentially, convert to studs.

We did this a couple of years ago. It worked…. OK. The rod does eventually come loose from the rivnuts, but does help with the problem of having to repeatedly thread into the nuts.

An easier approach is to drill through both sides of the 1x2 and use quick-release pins.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-09-11T18:16:07.105Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":193,"readers_count":192,"score":58.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":506208,"topic_slug":"bumper-attatchment","display_username":"CEF","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28649,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/bumper-attatchment/506208/10","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3736749,"name":"Michael Cameron","username":"holazola","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/holazola/{size}/260128_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-11T18:45:16.460Z","cooked":"

This is the way.
Whether you ultimately use studs or bolts, you should have a dedicated “Bumper Gun” on your cart, not used for anything else. Plenty of very cheap options here. WE use one of these, just because we have a bunch of small M12 tools in addition to our big M18 stuff.

Set the torque limiter as low as possible! This will prevent A) cross threaded starts B) Overtightened hardware that may strip threads / spin rivnuts after several dozen swaps.

Gaffer Tape the gun in an obnoxious color, and tape the bit to the gun. Make a holster. Yell at the students every time the holster is empty. Your life will be better.

image400×530 37.3 KB

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-09-11T18:45:16.460Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":190,"readers_count":189,"score":148.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":506208,"topic_slug":"bumper-attatchment","display_username":"Michael Cameron","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":66211,"username":"Suppdog222","name":"Will C","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/suppdog222/{size}/256515_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25547,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Sticking with Octopi mascots"},"post_url":"/t/bumper-attatchment/506208/11","custom_user_title":"Sticking with Octopi mascots","reactions":[{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3736752,"name":"philso","username":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-09-11T18:47:23.897Z","cooked":"

We have used these for the last 2-3 years and never had one come loose or pull out, even when we were subjected to very heavy defense.

We typically drive in 1/4-20 hex head bolts with a driver in a drill. The bolts are inexpensive so we just always have a bunch around.

These threaded inserts require a lot of torque to get the middle part to compress and spread out. It is best to use a high grade bolt for this like an automotive Grade 8 bolt. It is also good to have some long wrenches/ratchets to get the necessary torque.

amazon.com

Amazon.com: S25MG280 Steel PRE-BULBED Shank, Multi-Grip Rivet-NUT Gold ZINC...

S25MG280 STEEL PRE-BULBED SHANK, MULTI-GRIP RIVET-NUT GOLD ZINC FINISH, 1/4-20 X .020-.280 GRIP RANGE (PACK OF 25)

$18.33

Excellent. I agree that many teams do not set their Riv-nuts sufficiently and then suffer.

Sadly, it then makes them very allergic to using them in other places where they are often the simplest, fastest, strongest, lightest weight way to attach two things.

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2025-09-11T18:52:53.306Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":164,"readers_count":163,"score":37.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":506208,"topic_slug":"bumper-attatchment","display_username":"Michael Cameron","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":15467,"username":"philso","name":"philso","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/e68b1a/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25547,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Sticking with Octopi mascots"},"post_url":"/t/bumper-attatchment/506208/13","custom_user_title":"Sticking with Octopi mascots","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3736762,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-11T18:53:58.101Z","cooked":"

Clevis pins with cotters through everything are be a mixed bag. If you go this route, my recommendation would be to keep the studs and put pins in new holes next to the studs.

Why? Beware of taking a problem with two things that need to be aligned (bumpers to chassis) and adding a third floating thing (e.g., pins). We did this with a 2023 offseason 'bot and the 2024 competition 'bot and it was a nightmare.

If you’re just trying to align holes in the bumper assembly to chassis studs, you have one stationary object (chassis) and one moving object (bumper assembly) that you’re trying to exert some force upon, such that the holes drop over the studs.

If, instead, you have holes in both parts and are trying to drop a third something through those holes…it gets ugly. Anyone who has tried to attach farm implements to a tractor knows the pain of this. If the holes don’t line up perfectly, you now have to push hard on the bumpers while trying to precisely drop the pin into the hole – doubly so because it also has to line up with the bottom hole in the tube. You have far less strength to wrangle the bumper (because you’re minus one hand), plus a new precision task for the other hand. Or, you need more people whose motions need to be coordinated with your own. We had allen keys being used as spud wrenches during this process too.

Regardless, you’ll also need to get the pins through the top hole in the tube, then through the bottom hole. It’s not the end of the world, but it’s frustrating in crunch time and something else to go wrong.

Pins are far better than bolts, though. If you use bolts for this, you have the above problems, plus the fact that someone will violate the first rule of assembly and tighten one bolt before you get the rest inserted. Then, some of the bolts don’t fit…

Most rivnuts have little grooves for gripping the material they are installed in. If enough torque is applied, the grooves can slip and the rivnut becomes useless. If impact is applied to the screw before it is fully tightened, it can push it out so the grooves no longer hold onto the material.

With these fasteners, 4 “wings” extend out behind the material. The material is clamped between the large head and the wings. We have not been able to make one spin. The only way to remove it is to drill it.

There are similar fasteners sold on Amazon that are a silver color. They are made from thinner steel that appears to be softer. They don’t appear to work as well.

there’s a thing called quick release pins. it’s what we use to attach our bumpers to the frame. we also have a bracket bolted to the wood bumper frame but the bracket is attached to the chassis by quick release pins. they are super quick to remove. all you need to do is to press down a button and pull the pins out.
